importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The publication date of the article marks the release of the WMO's new report on global early-warning systems for extreme weather, emphasizing urgent action amid escalating climate-related disasters.

This date refers to the May 2025 event when scientists detected an imminent glacier collapse in Switzerland, leading to the evacuation of the village of Blatten. It illustrates a real-world success of early warning systems.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The year 2025 has seen a surge in extreme weather events globally, including floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US, highlighting the urgency of early warning systems.

keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack effective early-warning systems for extreme weather, leaving millions—especially in developing nations—vulnerable to climate-related disasters.
Disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems, with 90% of weather-related deaths occurring in developing countries over the past 50 years.

The WMO reports that 108 countries now use some form of multi-hazard early warning systems, up from 52 in the past decade, but still, half of assessed countries have only basic capacity and 16% have less than basic capacity.
Early warning systems are especially critical in fragile, conflict-affected, and violence-prone regions.
Progress is being made in Africa, with more countries establishing functioning websites and standardized alerts.
The WMO emphasizes that early warning leads to early action, and their mission is to not only warn but to empower communities to act.
Real-world examples such as the 2025 glacier collapse in Switzerland demonstrate how monitoring and early warnings can save lives and protect communities.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO), a UN agency, has issued a global call to action to strengthen early-warning systems for extreme weather events, noting that nearly half of all countries lack adequate monitoring and forecasting capabilities. With climate change driving more frequent and severe disasters, the WMO highlights that disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without such systems, and 90% of these deaths occur in developing nations. Despite progress—such as a rise in multi-hazard early warning systems from 52 to 108 countries—the assessment shows that 50% of countries have only basic capacity, and 16% have less. The article emphasizes that vulnerable regions, especially those affected by conflict or fragility, face the greatest risks. Real-world examples include the successful evacuation of Switzerland’s Blatten village in May 2025 due to a predicted glacier collapse, and widespread extreme weather events in 2025, including floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US. The WMO’s core message is that early warnings must translate into early action, empowering communities to respond and saving lives globally.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
